contextId.information: Anyone who doubts that God will help him is said to be like the water in the ocean or in large lakes, which keeps moving in different directions. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: For anyone who doubts is like a wave in the sea that is driven by the wind and tossed around

contextId.information: Here the flower simile is probably continued. As flowers do not die suddenly but instead fade away over a short time, so also the rich people may not die suddenly but instead take a little time to disappear. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: the rich man will fade away in the middle of his journey

contextId.information: This expression pictures God as an unchanging light, in contrast to the sun, moon, planets, and stars, which move across the sky and are always changing in their brightness. AT: "God does not change like the sun, moon, and stars, which appear and disappear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: With him there is no changing or shadow because of turning

contextId.information: James is using the traditional Hebrew idea of first fruits as a way to describe the value of the Christian believers to God. He implies that there will be many more believers in the future. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
A person who hears God's word but does not obey it is said to be like someone who looks in the mirror and then forgets what he looks like. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: For if anyone is a hearer of the word but not a doer, he is like a man who examines his natural face in a mirror

contextId.information: This expression continues the image of the law as a mirror.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: the person who looks carefully into the perfect law
